Figure 2: The graph for Example 5.

Example 5. Figure 2 shows a valid component $D$ whose root component $C_{0}=\left\{u_{1}, v_{1}\right\}$. Assume that the profit shares of its essential vertices $\left(u_{1}, u_{2}, u_{3}, u_{4}, v_{1}, v_{2}, v_{3}, v_{4}\right)$ are $(20,50,60,20,40,20,40,40)$, respectively. Clearly, $D$ has min on both sides at $\Omega=20$. Moving all of $D$ to Fully-Repaired will lead to a core imputation which is not leximin, as shown next.

The minimum fully repaired sub-component of $D$, Min-Sub1 $(D)$, consists of the graph induced on $\left(u_{1}, u_{2}, v_{1}, v_{2}\right)$, and it is added to Fully-Repaired in Step 2(b) of the algorithm. Furthermore, the fundamental components of $\left(D-\operatorname{Min}-\operatorname{Sub1}(D)\right.$, namely $\left(u_{3}, v_{3}\right)$ and $\left(u_{4}, v_{4}\right)$ are moved them back to Bin.

Next, while $\Omega=20,\left(u_{4}, v_{4}\right)$ is moved back to Active in Step 2(a). Also, since $\left(u_{4}, v_{3}\right)$ is a legitimate edge, in Step 2(c)(iii), $\left(u_{3}, v_{3}\right)$ is also moved back to Active. The two together form valid component $D^{\prime}=\left(u_{3}, u_{4}, v_{3}, v_{4}\right)$. At this point, $\Omega$ starts increasing again. When $\Omega=30$, $D^{\prime}$ is found to have min on both sides. Furthermore, since $\operatorname{Min}-\operatorname{Sub1}\left(D^{\prime}\right)=D^{\prime}$, it is moved into Fully-Repaired.

The final core imputation computed for essential vertices $\left(u_{1}, u_{2}, u_{3}, u_{4}, v_{1}, v_{2}, v_{3}, v_{4}\right)$ is given by $(20,50,70,30,40,20,30,30)$, respectively. This is the leximin core imputation.

Step 2(c)(iv): Edge $(i, j)$ connecting valid components $D$ and $D^{\prime}$, both in Active, has gone tight; clearly, $(i, j)$ must be incident at opposite sides of $D$ and $D^{\prime}$. Let $R$ be the component obtained by merging $D, D^{\prime}$ and $(i, j)$ in Step 2(c)(ii). W.l.o.g. assume that $D$ has min in left $(D)$ and $D^{\prime}$ has min in right $\left(D^{\prime}\right)$. If so, $i \in \operatorname{right}(D)$ and $j \in \operatorname{left}(D)$. Let $C_{0}$ and $C_{0}^{\prime}$ be the root fundamental components of $D$ and $D^{\prime}$, respectively and $C_{1}$ and $C_{1}^{\prime}$ be the fundamental components of $D$ and

$D^{\prime}$ containing $i$ and $j$, respectively.
Let $p$ and $p^{\prime}$ be the paths from $C_{0}$ to $C_{1}$ and from $C_{0}^{\prime}$ to $C_{1}^{\prime}$, in $D$ and $D^{\prime}$, respectively, as defined in Definition 18. Then the sub-component of $R$ consisting of $p$ and $p^{\prime}$, together with the edge $(i, j)$, is the minimum fully repaired sub-component of $R$; we will denote it by Min-Sub2 $(R)$. In Step 2(c)(iv), the algorithm moves Min-Sub2 $(R)$ to Fully-Repaired and decomposes $(R-\operatorname{Min-Sub2}(R))$ into fundamental components and moves them back to Bin.

Steps 2(c)(v) and 2(c)(vi): Edge $(i, j)$ connecting components $D$ and $D^{\prime}$ has gone tight, where $D^{\prime} \in$ Active, and $D \in$ Frozen in Step 2(c)(v) and $D \in$ Fully-Repaired in Step 2(c)(vi); observe that $D$ need not be a valid component, as defined in Definition 18. Let $R$ be the component obtained by merging $D, D^{\prime}$ and $(i, j)$ in Step 2(c)(ii). Let $C_{0}$ be the root fundamental component of $D^{\prime}$ and $C_{1}$ be the fundamental component of $D^{\prime}$ containing $i$.

Let $p$ be the path from $C_{0}$ to $C_{1}$ in $D^{\prime}$, as defined in Definition 18. Then the sub-component of $R$ consisting of $p$ together with the edge $(i, j)$, is the minimum fully repaired sub-component of $R$; we will denote it by Min-Sub3 $(R)$. In Step 2(c)(v), the algorithm moves Min-Sub3 $(R)$ to Frozen and in Step 2(c)(vi), it moves Min-Sub3 $(R)$ to Fully-Repaired. In either step, it decomposes $(R-\operatorname{Min-Sub3}(R))$ into fundamental components and moves them back to Bin.

The Cleanup in Step 2(d): The fundamental components which have been moved from Active back to Bin may have subpar tight edges connecting them. All such edges are removed from $T$ in Step 2(d) so these components can be independently improved in the future.

Remark 3. After the execution of Step 2(d) and before raising $\Omega$, it may turn out that for some fundamental component $C$ that just got moved from Active to Bin, $\min (C)=\Omega$. If so, $C$ needs to be moved back to Active. This may lead to the discovery of a legitimate edge incident at $C$ and the execution of a cascade of such events. All these events need to be executed before raising $\Omega$.

Lemma 8. Let $D$ be the component that is moved to (Frozen $\cup$ Fully-Repaired) at time $\Omega=t$. Then $\min (D)=t$.

Proof. In all four ways of moving a component $D$ to (Frozen $\cup$ Fully-Repaired), the root component of $D$, say $C_{0}$, is a also added. Since $\min (D)=\min \left(C_{0}\right)=t$, the lemma follows.

# 7.4 Proof of Correctness of Algorithm 1 

Our algorithm maintains the following second invariant:
Invariant 2: At any time $\Omega$ in the run of the algorithm, each fundamental component $C \in$ (Active $\cup$ Bin) satisfies $\min (C) \geq \Omega$.

Lemma 9. The algorithm maintains the Invariant 2.
Proof. In Step 1(e), $\Omega$ is initialized to the minimum profit share of an essential vertex under the starting core imputation $(u, v)$, and at this time, each fundamental component $C$ with

$\min (C)=\Omega$ is moved from Bin to Active. Therefore Invariant 2 is satisfied at the beginning of the algorithm.

At each time $\Omega$, each fundamental component $C \in$ Bin satisfying $\min (C)=\Omega$ is moved from Bin to Active. Thereafter, the increase in $\Omega$ and $\min (C)$ is synchronized. Therefore Invariant 2 is maintained.

Assume valid component $D \in$ Active and at time $\Omega, D$ has min on both sides, i.e., $D$ is fully repaired. Now, an appropriate sub-component of $D$ is moved from Active to Fully-Repaired in Step 2(c)(vi). The remaining fundamental components, say $C$, of $D$ are moved back to Bin. Since the latter satisfy $\min (C) \geq \Omega$, the fundamental components in Bin still satisfy Invariant 2.

Another possibility is that at time $\Omega$ in Step 2(c), a subpar edge $e$ from valid component $D \in$ Active to a component in (Active $\cup$ Frozen $\cup$ Fully-Repaired) becomes exactly tight. If so, the appropriate step in Step 2(c) is executed. This may also involve moving some fundamental components, say $C$, back to Bin. Since the latter satisfy $\min (C) \geq \Omega$, the fundamental components in Bin still satisfy Invariant 2.

Lemma 10. At any time $\Omega$ in the run of the algorithm, each valid component $D \in$ Active has the tree structure described in Definition 18.

Proof. The proof follows by an induction on the growth of $D$, i.e., the number of fundamental components in it. $D$ starts off when a fundamental component $C_{0}$ moves from Bin to Active. Assume $C_{0}$ has min in left $\left(C_{0}\right)$, the other case is analogous. If so, $D$ will be rotated clockwise. Clearly, no subpar over-tight edge with both endpoints in $D$ can go tight due to this rotation. However, a subpar over-tight edge can go tight from $D$ to a fundamental component $C \in$ Bin or a valid component $D^{\prime} \in$ Active. If so, the edge must go from $\operatorname{right}(D)$ to left $(C)$ or left $\left(D^{\prime}\right)$. In the first case, $C$ is added to $D$ and the tree structure is maintained. In the second case, it must be the case that $D^{\prime}$ is being rotated anti-clockwise, i.e., it has min in right $\left(D^{\prime}\right)$ and hence Step 2(c)(iv) kicks in and $D$ ceases to exist. The last possibility is that a subpar over-tight edge from $D$ to a component $D^{\prime} \in$ (Frozen $\cup$ Fully-Repaired) goes tight. If so, Step 2(c)(v) or 2(c)(vi) kicks in and again $D$ ceases to exist.

Let $S$ be a set of unique imputation components and fundamental components of $G$ and let $W_{S}$ denote the set of vertices of all these components, $W_{S} \subseteq(U \cup V)$. Let $H\left(W_{S}\right)$ denote the subgraph of $G$ induced on $W_{S}$. The edges of $H\left(W_{S}\right)$ inherit weights from $G$, i.e., $w: E \rightarrow \mathcal{Q}_{+}$.

Lemma 11. The following hold for the edge-weighted graph $H\left(W_{S}\right)$ :

1. The projection of a maximum weight matching of $G$ onto $H\left(W_{S}\right)$ is a maximum weight matching in $H\left(W_{S}\right)$. Furthermore every maximum weight matching of $H\left(W_{S}\right)$ arises in this manner.
2. The projection, onto $H\left(W_{S}\right)$, of the partition of vertices and edges of $G$ into essential, viable and subpar is the correct partition for $H\left(W_{S}\right)$.
3. The projection of a core imputation of $G$ onto $H\left(W_{S}\right)$ is a core imputation for $H\left(W_{S}\right)$.

Proof. 1. The crux of the matter lies in the following fact, which also gives the importance of moving entire unique imputation and fundamental components of $G$ into the subgraph $H\left(W_{S}\right)$. Obtain $E^{\prime}$ from $E$ by deleting all subpar edges and let $G^{\prime}=\left(U, V, E^{\prime}\right)$. Clearly the sets of maximum weight matchings of $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ are identical. Therefore each maximum weight matching in $G$ consists of a union of maximum weight matchings in the unique imputation and fundamental components of $G$.
Obviously the projection of a maximum weight matching of $G$ onto $H\left(W_{S}\right)$ is a matching in $H\left(W_{S}\right)$. Suppose for contradiction $H\left(W_{S}\right)$ has a heavier maximum weight matching, say $M$. Then $M$ together with maximum weight matchings in the fundamental components of $G$ which are not in $S$ will be a heavier matching in $G$, leading to a contradiction.
2. This is a corollary of the previous assertion.
3. Let $p$ be a core imputation of $G$ and let $w$ and $w^{\prime}$ be the weights of maximum weight matchings in $G$ and $H\left(W_{S}\right)$, respectively. By definition, $p\left(W_{S}\right) \geq w^{\prime}$. By the first part, the maximum weight matching in the induced subgraph on $\left((U \cup V)-W_{S}\right)$ has weight $w-w^{\prime}$. Therefore $p\left((U \cup V)-W_{S}\right) \geq\left(w-w^{\prime}\right)$. Also, the worth of the game $G$ is

$$
w=p\left(W_{S}\right)+p\left((U \cup V)-W_{S}\right) \geq w^{\prime}+\left(w-w^{\prime}\right)=w
$$

Therefore $p\left(W_{S}\right)=w^{\prime}$.
Finally observe that for any sub-coalition $W^{\prime} \subseteq W_{S}$, its worth is the same in $G$ and $H\left(W_{S}\right)$, and by definition, $p\left(W^{\prime}\right)$ is at least the worth of $W^{\prime}$. Hence the projection of $p$ onto $H\left(W_{S}\right)$ is a core imputation for $H\left(W_{S}\right)$.

At any time $\Omega=t$ in the run of the algorithm, consider the moment when $\Omega$ is just about to be increased, i.e, the cascade of events described in Remark 3 have all been executed. At this moment, let $W_{t}$ be the set of vertices of all components which are in (Frozen $\cup$ Fully-Repaired); clearly $W_{t} \subseteq(U \cup V)$. Let $H_{t}$ denote the subgraph of $G$ induced on $W_{t}$.

Lemma 12. The profit shares of vertices of $W_{t}$ form the leximin core imputation for the graph $H_{t}$.
Proof. By the third statement of Lemma 11, the profit shares of vertices of $W_{t}$ form a core imputation for the graph $H_{t}$. Let $F$ denote the set of vertices of the unique imputation components in Frozen at the start of the algorithm. The proof follows by an induction on the growth of $W_{t}$, i.e., the number of components (which in general are unions of fundamental components and legitimate edges) that are added to (Frozen $\cup$ Fully-Repaired). Clearly the assertion holds for $F$, which proves the basis of the induction.

For the induction step, assume that the assertion holds for $W_{t}$ and we wish to prove it for $W_{t^{\prime}}$ where $t^{\prime}>t$ and at time $t^{\prime}$, one more component, say $D$, is added to (Frozen $\cup$ Fully-Repaired) and hence to $W_{t^{\prime}}$. Clearly, $\min (D)=t^{\prime}$. By Lemma 8 each component $D^{\prime}$ that was added to (Frozen $\cup$ Fully-Repaired) until time $t$ satisfied $\min \left(D^{\prime}\right) \leq t$.

There are two cases. If $D$ was added to Fully-Repaired because it was fully repaired, then its imputation cannot be leximin-improved and the assertion follows. If $D$ was added to (Frozen $\cup$

Fully-Repaired) because a subpar edge $e$ just went tight, then the only way of leximin-improving $D$ is to leximin-deteriorate the current imputation of $W_{t}$ (since edge $e$ cannot be allowed to go under-tight). For each component $D^{\prime}$ in $W_{t}, \min \left(D^{\prime}\right)<\min (D)$. Therefore, this change will leximin-deteriorate the overall imputation for $W_{t^{\prime}}$. Hence the current imputation of $W_{t^{\prime}}$ is the leximin core imputation for the graph $H_{t^{\prime}}$. The lemma follows.

Theorem 7. Let $M$ denote the weight of a maximum weight edge in the given instance. Then, Algorithm 1 will terminate with a leximin core imputation by time $M / 2$.

Proof. By Lemmas 12, and 9 at each time $t$, the profit shares of vertices of $W_{t}$ form the leximin core imputation for the graph $H_{t}$ and the profit share of each vertex in $(U \cup V)-W_{t}$ is $>t$.

Consider the extreme case that there is an essential edge $e$ having weight $M$ which starts off with profit shares of 0 and $M$ on its endpoints. If $e$ does not get moved into (Frozen $\cup$ Fully-Repaired) before time $M / 2$, then it will be fully-repaired at time $M / 2$. Clearly, all other fundamental components will get moved into (Frozen $\cup$ Fully-Repaired) by that time either because they are fully-repaired or have a tight edge to a component in (Frozen $\cup$ Fully-Repaired). The theorem follows.

Theorem 8. Algorithm 1 runs in strongly polynomial time; in particular, in time $O\left(m^{2+o(1)}\right)$.
Proof. In Section 6.1, we showed that the time required to classify vertices and edges requires a total time of $O\left(m^{2+o(1)}\right)$. Below we will show that the rest of the steps of Algorithm 1 require time $O(m n \log n)$, using the data structure of Fibonacci Heap [FT87], which executes operations of insert and find-min in $O(1)$ time and delete-min and delete in $O(\log n)$ time, amortized. Since the first term dominates the second, the theorem follows.

We will partition a run of Algorithm 1 into epochs. The first epoch starts with the start of Algorithm 1 and an epoch ends when a component gets moved to (Frozen $\cap$ Fully-Repaired), i.e., in Step 2(b), 2(c)(iv), 2(c)(v) or 2(c)(vi). Clearly there are at most $O(n)$ epochs.

There will be at most $m+n$ entries in the Fibonacci Heap, one corresponding to each edge and each fundamental component. The key of each entry specifies the time at which it will participate in an event. For each fundamental component $C \in \operatorname{Bin}$, there is an entry whose key is $\min (C)$, since $C$ will move into Active when $\Omega=\min (C)$. Once a fundamental component $C$ moves into Active, in Step 2(a) or 2(c)(iii), all subpar edges incident at $C$ are inserted in the Fibonacci Heap with the appropriate key.

The minimum key in the Fibonacci Heap indicates the next event that will happen. Hence there is no need to decrease $\Omega$ continuously; it can be dropped in discrete steps. When Step 2(d) is executed, all the edges participating in the cleanup are deleted from the Fibonacci Heap. These $O(m)$ operations, which take $O(m \log n)$ time, dominate the rest of the operations.

# Algorithm 2. (Algorithm for Leximax Core Imputation) 

1. Initialization:
(a) $(u, v) \leftarrow$ an arbitrary core imputation.
(b) $T_{0} \leftarrow$ essential and viable edges; $H_{0}=\left(U, V, T_{0}\right)$.
(c) Frozen $\leftarrow$ unique imputation components of $H_{0}$.
(d) Bin $\leftarrow$ fundamental components of $H_{0}$.
(e) $\Omega \leftarrow$ maximum profit share of an essential vertex under $(u, v)$.
(f) $T \leftarrow T_{0}$.
2. While (Bin $\cup$ Active) $\neq \varnothing$ do:

At unit rate, decrease $\Omega$ and repair all components $C \in$ Active.
If:
(a) $\exists C \in$ Bin s.t. $\min (C)=\Omega$ then move $C$ to Active
(b) $\exists C \in$ Active is fully repaired then move Max-Sub1(C) to Fully-Repaired and the fundamental components of $\left(C-\operatorname{Max}_{\text {Sub1 }}(C)\right.$ ) to Bin.
(c) $\exists$ legitimate edge $(i, j)$.

Assume its endpoints are in $C$ and $C^{\prime}$, where $C \in$ Active.
i. $T \leftarrow T \cup\{(i, j)\}$.
ii. Merge $C, C^{\prime}$ and $(i, j)$ into one component, say $D$.
iii. If $C^{\prime} \in$ Bin then move $D$ to Active.
iv. If $C^{\prime} \in$ Active then move Max-Sub2(D) to Fully-Repaired and the fundamental components of $\left(D-\operatorname{Max}_{\text {Sub2 }}(D)\right.$ ) to Bin.
v. If $C^{\prime} \in$ Frozen then move Max-Sub3(D) to Frozen and the fundamental components of $\left(D-\operatorname{Max}_{\text {Sub3 }}(D)\right.$ ) to Bin.
vi. If $C^{\prime} \in$ Fully-Repaired then move Max-Sub3(D) to Fully-Repaired and the fundamental components of $\left(D-\operatorname{Max}_{\text {Sub3 }}(D)\right.$ ) to Bin.
(d) Cleanup $T$ : remove all tight subpar edges connecting fundamental components in Bin.
3. Output: Output the current imputation and HALT.

# 8 Algorithm for Leximax Core Imputation 

Algorithm 2 computes the leximax core imputation for the assignment game, $G=(U, V, E), w$ : $E \rightarrow \mathcal{Q}_{+}$. It differs from Algorithm 1 in the following ways:

1. In Step 1(e), $\Omega$ is initialized to the maximum profit share of an essential vertex under the initial core imputation $(u, v)$ computed in Step 1(a).
2. Whereas in Algorithm 1, $\Omega$ is raised at unit rate, in Algorithm 2, it is lowered at unit rate.
3. Definition 19 plays a role analogous to that of Definition 15. Furthermore, for Algorithm 2, we will say that component $C$ is fully repaired if it has max on both sides.
4. Repairing a Component: If component $C$ has max in left $(C)$, then $C$ needs to be rotated anti-clockwise and if it has max in right $(C)$, it needs to be rotated clockwise.
5. The previous change will change the definition of valid component appropriately. Furthermore, the definitions of Min-Sub1, Min-Sub2 and Min-Sub3 will change appropriately and we will denote the resulting sub-components by Max-Sub1, Max-Sub2 and Max-Sub3, respectively.
6. The proofs of correctness and running time of Algorithm 2 are analogous to that of Algorithm 1 .

Definition 19. At any point in the Algorithm, for any connected component $C$ of $H, \max (C)$ will denote the largest profit share of an essential vertex in $C$. We will say that $C$ has max on both sides if there is a vertex in left $(C)$ as well one in $\operatorname{right}(C)$ whose profit is $\max (C)$. Otherwise, we will say that $C$ has max in left $(C)(\operatorname{right}(C))$ if there is a vertex in left $(C)(\operatorname{right}(C))$ whose profit is $\max (C)$.

Theorem 9. Algorithm 2 computes the leximax core imputation in strongly polynomial time; in particular, in time $O\left(m^{2+o(1)}\right)$.

## 9 Discussion

Is there a simpler combinatorial procedure, than Algorithm 1, for finding the leximin core imputation for the assignment game? Before answering this question, we consider the following problem: Find the set of essential vertices which are assigned the smallest profit in the leximin core imputation.

An LP-based algorithm will require ideas from [FRT85] - for identifying the set of always-active constraints. How about an efficient combinatorial algorithm? The only method we are aware of is to run Algorithm 1 for the first epoch (see Theorem 8 for a definition) and pick the set of essential vertices having the smallest profits in $V_{t}$. This leads us to believe that the answer to the question stated above is "No".

Interestingly enough, the two principles underlying primal-dual algorithms also underlie algorithms for finding Nash equilibria for a two-player zero-sum game, namely:

1. Finding globally optimal solutions by making only local improvements and
2. Two processes, a minimizer and a maximizer, alternately making improvements to dual entities by responding to each other's progress.

For the Nash equilibrium problem, the two regret minimization algorithms take local improvement steps in the direction of the gradient, and the average of the strategies played converges to the set of Nash equilibria. This is a folklore fact that traces back to at least the works by Hannan [Han57] and Foster and Vohra [FV97]; see also the recent paper [APFS22].
Finally, here are some open problems.

1. Where in the polytope of optimal dual solutions to LP (2) do the leximin and leximax core imputations lie? Characterize these points; see also Section 1.1.
2. The running time given in Theorem 8 is dominated by the time required to classify vertices and edges, see Section 6.1. Is there a way of speeding up this part thereby speeding up the entire algorithm?

abstract:
The classic paper of Shapley and Shubik \cite{Shapley1971assignment}
characterized the core of the assignment game. We observe that a sub-coalition
consisting of one player (or a set of players from the same side of the
bipartition) can make zero profit, and therefore its profit under a core
imputation can be an arbitrary amount. Hence an arbitrary core imputation makes
{\em no fairness guarantee at the level of individual agents}. Can this
deficiency be addressed by picking a ``good'' core imputation?
  To arrive at an appropriate solution concept, we give specific criteria for
picking a special core imputation, and we undertake a detailed comparison of
four solution concepts. Leximin and leximax core imputations come out as clear
winners; we define these to be {\em equitable core imputations}. These
imputations achieve ``fairness'' in different ways: whereas leximin tries to
make poor agents more rich, leximax tries to make rich agents less rich.
  We give combinatorial strongly polynomial algorithms for computing these
imputations via a novel adaptation of the classical primal-dual paradigm. The
``engine'' driving them involves insights into core imputations obtained via
complementarity. It will not be surprising if our work leads to new uses of
this powerful technique. Furthermore, we expect more work on computing the
leximin and leximax core imputations of other natural games, in addition to the
recent follow-up work \cite{Leximin-max}.
